questions.question: A 62-year-old male patient is having complaints of loss of vision in the form of a curtain coming down in front of the right eye. He has a history of 2 episodes of strokes, after which he has left-sided sensory and motor loss limited to the face and neck. Which of the following blood vessels might be stenosed in this case?

options.C: First part of the left subclavian artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Carotid artery Explanation: The condition is diagnosed as Carotid artery stenosis , having clinical features of face and neck paralysis along with Amaurosis fugax (loss of vision in the form of a curtain coming down in front of the eye). Carotid artery stenosis Carotid artery stenosis may cause TIAs (Transient Ischemic Attacks), which are short-lived mini strokes and are often recurrent, causing unilateral motor or sensory loss in the arm, leg or face. They are caused by the distal embolisation of platelet thrombi that form on the atheromatous plaque and enter the cerebral circulation. They are considered as a warning of impending major stroke. Duplex scan is done for assessment. Indications for Endarterectomy: Stenosis of more than or equal to 50% Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia Arm/leg paresthesia Hemianopia Dysphasia Sensory loss or visual inattention or neglect. Amaurosis fugax is the temporary loss of vision due decreased blood supply to the retina to blockage of arteries. It is presented as a feeling of a curtain coming down in front of the eyes. Left vertebral artery (Option A): Stenosis can cause symptoms such as vertigo, numbness in hands and feet, drop attacks, nausea, vomiting, slurred speech, ataxia, abnormal gait, loss of vision, and double vision. This condition is known as vertebrobasilar insufficiency (VBI). 1st part of left subclavian artery (Option C): In subclavian artery stenosis, there is this characteristic “Subclavian steal syndrome” which us due to reversal of blood from ipsilateral vertebral artery leading to weakness, syncope, vertigo, dizziness, ataxia, visual abnormalities. Superior mesenteric vein (Option D): Occlusion can lead to mesenteric venous thrombosis (MVT). Abdominal pain is the main complaint in this case along with hematochezia or melena if not treated early. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1008

questions.question: A 67-year-old male was having complaints of sudden onset of severe chest pain, which was radiating to his back, and suddenly, he went unconscious. He was chronically hypertensive, a drug defaulter, and was having weakness, dizziness and dyspnea for 1 day. His current BP is 90/50 mm Hg, and his Heart Rate is 140 bpm. What is the best investigation of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) Explanation: The above given scenario is an unstable case of Aortic dissection, and the investigation of choice is TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography). Aortic Dissection It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen. Clinical features: Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the interscapular region Renal pain and renal failure Paraplegia Syncope Weakness Hypotension or shock Investigations: If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice. (Option A) In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal. Chest x-ray (Option D) reveals widening of the mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion. TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part Aortography (Option B) is the investigation of choice for chronic mesenteric ischemia.

questions.question: Which of the following signs is seen in Arteriovenous fistula?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Nicoladoni’s sign Explanation: Nicoladoni’s sign/ Branham sign is seen in arteriovenous fistula. Arteriovenous Fistula (AVF) AVF is a communication between an artery and a vein that may be either congenital or acquired (trauma or surgical). Structurally, they are arterialised (become dilated, tortuous and thick-walled). Physiologically, there is an increase in venous return (as blood starts flowing from arteries to veins, which causes an increase in cardiac output, which in turn results in an increase in systolic BP, leading to cardiac failure. On examination, there is a presence of pulsatile swelling, a thrill and auscultation reveals machinery murmur (buzzing continuous murmur) Nicoladoni’s / Branham’s sign is observed in AVF: On pressing the artery proximal to the fistula, there is a decrease in the size of the pulsatile mass, disappearance of palpable thrill and decrease in heart rate. Murphy’s sign (Option A): Pain during inspiration while palpating the right subcostal area is termed Murphy’s sign. It is seen in acute cholecystitis. Brudzinski’s sign (Option B): In meningitis, neck stiffness causes patient's hips and knees to flex when the neck is flexed; this is Brudzinski’s sign. Hegar’s sign (Option C): Softening of the cervix in pregnancy is known as hegar’s sign Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1023, 1024

questions.question: A 35-year-old female experiences numbness and tingling in her right arm, worsened by arm elevation. During examination, she abducts her arms to 90° with external rotation, flexes her elbows to 90°, and opens and closes her hands for 3 minutes, which reproduces her symptoms. Which test was most likely performed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Roos Test Explanation: The scenario describes the Roos test (also known as the Elevated Arm Stress Test), which is used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The test involves the patient abducting their arms to 90°, externally rotating them, flexing the elbows to 90°, and repeatedly opening and closing the hands for 3 minutes. Reproduction of symptoms like numbness or tingling during this test indicates a positive result, suggestive of TOS. Roos Test Common provocative diagnostic tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Test Maneuver Result Adson's Test (Option A) Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply. Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse. Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B) Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°). The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes. Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated. Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D) Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed. Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists. Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions. Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3. Wright's test (Option C) is a clinical sign in which the radial pulse weakens or disappears when the arm is abducted and externally rotated. Common provocative diagnostic tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Test Maneuver Result Adson's Test (Option A) Arm abducted 30° and maximally extended. Patient extends neck, turns head toward the ipsilateral side, and inhales deeply. Decrease or absence of ipsilateral radial pulse. Elevated Arm Stress Test (EAST) / Roos Test (Option B) Arms in "surrender" position (abducted 90°, external rotation, elbows flexed 90°). The patient slowly opens and closes hands for 3 minutes. Pain, paresthesia, heaviness, or weakness precipitated. Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT) / Elvey Test (Option D) Position 1: Arms abducted 90°, elbows flexed. Position 2: Active dorsiflexion of wrists. Position 3: Tilt head (ear to shoulder) in both directions. Symptoms in the ipsilateral arm (Position 1 & 2); Contralateral symptoms in Position 3. Wright's test (Option C) is a clinical sign in which the radial pulse weakens or disappears when the arm is abducted and externally rotated. Adsons test Elvey Test

questions.question: A 23-year-old competitive swimmer presents with progressive weakness and tingling in his right hand. On examination, there is wasting of the small muscles of the hand and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand and forearm. Which of the following nerves is most likely compressed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ulnar nerve (C8-T1) Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), where the ulnar nerve (C8-T1) is commonly compressed and presents with muscle wasting in the hand and sensory loss in the medial hand and forearm. TOS often presents in athletes like swimmers, who frequently use overhead movements. The ulnar nerve is vulnerable in TOS because it passes through the thoracic outlet and can be compressed by anatomical structures such as a cervical rib or tight scalene muscles. Thoracic outlet syndrome: Category Details Boundaries Upper: Collarbone (Clavicle) Lower: First Rib Anterior: Scalenus Anterior Muscle Posterior: Scalenus Medius Muscle Medial: Scalene Triangle (formed by the Scalenus Anterior, Scalenus Medius, and First Rib) Predisposing Factors Cervical Rib, Cervical Hematoma (Trauma), Pancoast Tumor, Osteoarthritis, Long Transverse Process of C7 Clinical Manifestations Neurogenic TOS: Pain, numbness, and tingling due to nerve compression Arterial TOS: Pain, coldness, and paleness due to impaired arterial blood flow Venous TOS: Swelling, pain, and discolouration due to impaired venous return Median nerve (C5-T1) (Option A) typically causes symptoms like carpal tunnel syndrome, affecting the thumb, index, and middle fingers, which are not described here. Radial nerve (C5-T1) (Option C) compression would lead to weakness in wrist and finger extension, commonly known as "wrist drop." Axillary nerve(C5-C6) (Option D) involvement leads to deltoid muscle weakness and loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder, which is not observed in this case. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21 Edition, Page 1801,1830 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 415

questions.question: Which of the following is the most preferred vascular graft for CABG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) LIMA Explanation: The most preferred vascular graft for CABG is LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery). Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) CABG is a procedure done by using a vascular graft for bypassing the blocked site of arteries and allowing the flow of blood to the heart muscles. Various types of grafts can be used as per need. For example, the most preferred graft for CABG is LIMA (Option D) , but the Long saphenous vein is more commonly used due to its extra length and it is easy to handle (Option A) . Dacron, polyurethane, and ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene) are examples of synthetic vascular grafts. (Option B and C) . Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 946-953

questions.question: A 48-year-old male presents with retrosternal chest pain, which was radiation to the left arm and shoulder. He has a previous history of acute myocardial infarction. CABG was advised, but the patient is insisting on using synthetic graft and wants to know more about it. Which of the following is the most preferred synthetic vascular graft for CABG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dacron Explanation: The best synthetic type of vascular graft for CABG is Dacron. It is the most preferred vascular graft for supra-inguinal bypass surgery. Indications for CABG: Triple vessel stenosis Left main stem stenosis Chronic stable angina Angina with persistent chest pain >70% blockage of coronary vessels Classification of Vascular grafts: Bioprosthetic grafts LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery) Long saphenous vein: Most commonly used in infra-inguinal surgeries due to small and medium-sized vessels (Option D) Synthetic grafts Dacron: Most commonly used synthetic graft in supra inguinal surgeries due to large vessels. (Option C) Polyurethane (Option A) ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene) (Option B) Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 949, 950

questions.question: Based on the Stanford classification, which type of aortic dissection is shown below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Type A Explanation: According to the Stanford classification, the given image is classified as Type A aortic dissection. Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer and creating a false lumen. There are 2 classifications, both of which are widely used for Aortic dissection. DeBakey Classification (Based on the pattern of dissection) Type I Both ascending and descending aorta are involved Type II Only the ascending aorta is involved Type III Only the descending aorta is involved Stanford Classification (Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection) Type A Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved. (Option A) (It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification) Type B Only the descending aorta is involved. (Option B) (It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with back pain, and imaging shows a thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm starting at the sixth intercostal space and extending to just above the renal arteries. According to the Crawford classification, which type does this aneurysm correspond to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Type V Explanation: Given the description, the patient is diagnosed with Type V thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm Crawford's classification of thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm: Type Involvement I Descending thoracic aorta to above renal arteries. II Descending thoracic aorta to below renal arteries. III From the sixth intercostal space to below renal arteries. IV The entire abdominal aorta from the twelfth intercostal space to the aortic bifurcation. V Portion of the thoracic aorta below the sixth intercostal space to above renal arteries. questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.0 cm in diameter, detected during routine surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Endovascular aneurysm repair Explanation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm : For an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that has reached 6.0 cm in diameter, surgical intervention is generally recommended due to the high risk of rupture. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a minimally invasive surgical approach that is often preferred for eligible patients, given its lower complication rates compared to open surgery. Surveillance is appropriate for smaller aneurysms, and medical management, including blood pressure control and lifestyle modifications, is essential but not sufficient alone for an aneurysm of this size. Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA): Aspect Details Surveillance Small AAAs (3.0–3.9 cm): Monitor every 2–3 years using ultrasound. Medium AAAs (4.0–5.4 cm): Monitor every 6–12 months with ultrasound. Large AAAs ( ≥ 5.5 cm): Surgical intervention recommended; if not, frequent imaging and clinical review. Medical Management Risk Factor Modification : Smoking Cessation Blood Pressure Control Cholesterol Management: Statins recommended. Surgical Intervention I ndications for Surgery: Aneurysm Diameter ≥ 5.5 cm (High risk of rupture) Rapid Growth: >0.5 cm increase in six months. Symptomatic AAAs : Consider surgery. Surgical Options : Open Surgical Repair: Using a Dacron graft which is durable and has higher morbidity. Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR): Less invasive, requires long-term surveillance for complications. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21 Edition, Pages 1747-1751

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of bacterial endocarditis presents with sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. A CT scan of the head is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the haemorrhage in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ruptured mycotic aneurysm. Explanation: In this clinical scenario, the patient has a history of bacterial endocarditis, which significantly raises the likelihood of developing mycotic aneurysms. These aneurysms often occur in cerebral arteries due to septic emboli from the heart lodging in the vessel walls, leading to infection and weakening of the artery. This condition can result in a subarachnoid hemorrhage if the aneurysm ruptures . In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), the rupture of a berry aneurysm

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents with a pulsatile mass in the right groin following recent arterial catheterisation. Doppler ultrasound reveals an aneurysm. Which characteristic best describes this type of aneurysm?

options.A: Involves all three arterial wall layers
options.C: Wall composed of fibrous tissue only

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Wall composed of fibrous tissue only. Explanation: With the given history, the patient has developed a Pseudoaneurysm post catheterisation. Aspect True Aneurysm False (Pseudoaneurysm) Definition Involves all three layers of the arterial wall. Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel. (Option A ruled out) Wall Structure Intima, media, and adventitia are involved. Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach. Morphology Fusiform or saccular. Typically spherical or ovoid.(Option B ruled out) Aetiology Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions. Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture.(Option D ruled out) Clinical Features May be asymptomatic until complications arise. Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain. Common Locations Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac). Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal). Diagnosis Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI. Detected by ultrasound or angiography. Management Surgical repair or endovascular techniques. Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection). Types of Aneurysms: Type of Aneurysm Characteristics Common Locations Associated Conditions Fusiform Aneurysm Dilation affects the entire circumference of the vessel Abdominal aorta, iliac Atherosclerosis Saccular Aneurysm Dilation affects only part of the vessel circumference Cerebral arteries, aortic Atherosclerosis, infection Mycotic Aneurysm Caused by infection (Bacterial) Usually cerebral or aortic Endocarditis, septicemia Aortic Root Aneurysm Dilates the aortic root, leading to aortic regurgitation Aortic root Connective tissue disorders, syphilis Popliteal Aneurysm Most common peripheral aneurysm Behind the knee Atherosclerosis, embolisation Femoral Aneurysm Can be true or false, often related to surgery Groin area Post-surgical complication Iliac Aneurysm Often coexists with AAA Iliac arteries Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA)

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe abdominal pain that is disproportionate to physical examination findings. He also reports vomiting and the passage of blood in his stool. Given his history and clinical presentation, which artery is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Superior Mesenteric Artery Explanation: Given the patient’s presentation, the diagnosis is Acute mesenteric ischemia and the most common artery involved is Superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which supplies a large portion of the small intestine and part of the colon. Occlusion of the SMA is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia, leading to sudden, severe abdominal pain, particularly in patients with atrial fibrillation. Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (AMI): Aspects Description Definition Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis. Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Clinical Features Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings. Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock. Risk Factors Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure. Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis. Others: Hypercoagulable states. Radiological Features CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign , bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas. Management Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control. Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm.

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman presents with episodic colour changes in her fingers triggered by cold temperatures and stress. The episodes follow a characteristic sequence. What is the correct sequence of events in the skin colour changes seen in the Raynaud phenomenon? → Cyanosis → Pallor → Pallor → Rubor → Cyanosis → Rubor → Pallor → Cyanosis
questions.explanation: → Cyanosis → Rubor Correct Answer: C) Pallor → Cyanosis → Rubor Explanation: Sequence of events in Raynaud’s phenomenon: Pallor : The initial phase where the skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow and vasospasm. Cyanosis : Followed by a blue or purple colour due to continued reduced blood flow and lack of oxygen. Rubor : The final phase is where the skin turns red as blood flow returns and the area warms up. Category Description Definition Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress. Clinical Features Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow. Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood. Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling. Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers. Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase. Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase. Types Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease): Occurs without underlying disease. More common and has a better prognosis. Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome): Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus). Often more severe. Management Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation. Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators. Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine. Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases. Diagnosis Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers. Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes. Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe pain in his left leg. The leg appears pale and feels cold to the touch, and the patient is unable to move or feel his toes. On examination, no pulses are detectable below the knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute limb ischemia Explanation: This patient’s symptoms strongly suggest Acute limb ischemia , a serious condition caused by a sudden blockage of blood flow to the limb. It is typically recognised by the "5 P's": Pain : Intense, sudden pain in the affected limb. Pallor: The limb appears pale due to reduced blood flow. Pulselessness: The absence of a pulse beyond the site of the blockage. Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling in the limb. Paralysis: The inability to move the limb due to muscle weakness. Prompt recognition and treatment are essential to restore blood flow and prevent permanent damage to the limb. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) (Option A): DVT typically presents with swelling, pain, and redness in the affected leg, but it does not usually cause the leg to be pale and cold or result in a loss of pulses. The loss of pulses and coldness are more indicative of arterial rather than venous issues. Chronic Venous Insufficiency (Option C): Chronic venous insufficiency generally causes symptoms such as swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes over time. It does not typically present with sudden onset severe pain, pallor, coldness, or loss of pulses. Cellulitis (Option D): Cellulitis usually presents with redness, warmth, swelling, and tenderness of the skin. It typically does not cause loss of pulses, coldness, or the inability to move or feel the toes, which are more consistent with ischemic conditions rather than infection. Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 954

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in his left leg, which has become cold and pale. On examination, there is an absence of distal pulses. Imaging reveals a large saddle embolus at the aortic bifurcation. What is the most appropriate catheter to use for embolectomy in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fogarty catheter Explanation: Fogarty catheter – Specifically designed for embolectomy or thrombectomy. catheter - wikidoc" data-tags="" height="597" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/YFEeqe3510j3V6LGq6E81740043078.png" width="500" /> Embolectomy using Fogarty catheter: Seldinger catheter (Option A) is used for guiding wires in vascular procedures but not for embolectomy. Swan-Ganz catheter (Option B) is primarily used for measuring pulmonary artery pressures and cardiac output, not for embolectomy. Tenckhoff catheter (Option D) is typically used in peritoneal dialysis and is not applicable in vascular procedures like embolectomy.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with end-stage renal disease is scheduled for the creation of a surgically created arteriovenous (AV) fistula to facilitate long-term hemodialysis. Which of the following is the most commonly used type of AV fistula for this purpose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cimino-Brescia fistula Explanation: The Cimino-Brescia fistula is the most commonly used AV fistula for hemodialysis access. It involves connecting the radial artery to the cephalic vein at the wrist, creating a durable and reliable access point for hemodialysis. Surgically created Arterio-Venous fistula : It is a connection made between an artery and a vein, typically in the arm, and is most commonly used for patients with end-stage renal disease who require hemodialysis. Aspect Details Purpose Used for hemodialysis Provides high blood flow for effective dialysis Site Selection Prefer distal placement Non-dominant arm is typically used Arterial Quality Requires a strong arterial pulse for success Vein Preservation Avoid placing venous lines in the arm intended for fistula Examples of Surgically created fistulas are: Brescia-Cimino fistula: It is created between the Radial artery and the Cephalic vein. Snuff Box fistula: It is created between the Posterior branch of the radial artery and Cephalic vein (Option C) Feinberg fistula: It is created between the Radial artery and the Basilic vein. Blalock-Taussig shunt Option B): It is a surgically created AV shunt used primarily to increase pulmonary blood flow in patients with congenital heart defects like tricuspid atresia, tetralogy of Fallot etc. It is not used for hemodialysis. Axillary-axillary loop graft (Option D): This loop graft is typically used when the more common sites for AV fistulas are not viable. It is less common than the Cimino-Brescia fistula for hemodialysis.

questions.question: A 46-year-old male presents with intense pain in his left leg along with the following lesion. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Arterial ulcer Explanation: The most probable diagnosis of the given ulcer is Arterial ulcer. It occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium sized arteries leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region. They may present as painful erosions, located between the toes, dorsum of feet, on the shin and around malleoli. Characteristic features of arterial ulcers: Punched-out edges are seen It is intensely painful Distal pulses are not palpable Thin, shiny skin is seen Loss of hair in the area Brittle nails are seen Clinical features of different ulcers are as follows: Venous ulcer (Option B) Arterial ulcer (Option C) Neuropathic ulcer (Option A) Pressure ulcer (Option D) Site Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf) At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs. Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc Appearance Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia. Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer. Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here. Punched out ulcer with bone as a base. Cause Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins. This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region. It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients . It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body. Characteristics It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless. It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again. It is intensely painful, distal pulses are not palpable, associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region. Also known as diabetic ulcer since it is seen in diabetic patients. It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries,

questions.question: A 35-year-old male with a 12-year history of smoking presents with severe rest pain and discoloration of the left lower limb's digits as shown below. He has experienced worsening pain in this limb for the past 2 days, following 3 months of discomfort. What is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Amputation Explanation: This patient presents with advanced peripheral arterial disease , most likely Buerger’s disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans) , as suggested by: History of chronic smoking Rest pain in the limb Black discoloration of the toes (indicating dry gangrene ) Progressive worsening of symptoms over months The blackened digits in the image represent non-viable tissue , which is: Irreversible A source of pain At risk of infection Amputation is required at this stage to: Remove gangrenous tissue Prevent secondary infection Relieve intractable rest pain Given the presence of dry gangrene and severe rest pain, amputation is the definitive management at this stage. Lumbar sympathectomy (Option A): Used in early disease to improve blood flow and relieve rest pain when tissue is still viable . It is not effective once gangrene develops. Abstinence from smoking (Option B): Essential for disease control and to prevent progression in early stages, but does not reverse established gangrene. Vasodilators (Option D): They may help in early ischemia by improving

questions.question: A 56-year-old male presents with sudden pain and numbness in his right lower limb for 1 day. On examination, the limb is cold and pale and exhibits loss of sensory and mild motor functions. Doppler studies reveal only venous signals. What grade of Rutherford's classification is this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grade IIB Explanation: The above clinical scenario is a case of Acute Limb Ischemia (ALI) with Grade IIB of Rutherford’s classification. Rutherford’s classification of acute limb ischemia: Grade Category Sensory loss Motor deficit Arterial doppler signals Venous doppler signals Prognosis I (Option A) Viable none none Audible Audible No immediate threat IIA (Option B ) Marginally Threatened None or minimal (toes) none Inaudible Audible Salvageable if promptly treated IIB (Option C) Immediately threatened More than toes Mild/moderate Inaudible Audible Salvageable with immediate revascularisation III (Option D) Irreversible Profound or insensate Paralyzed Inaudible Inaudible Limb is irreversibly damaged, major tissue loss, and amputation. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1012

questions.question: A 38-year-old chronic smoker presents with lower limb pain during walking for 2 weeks. Examination reveals an ankle-to-brachial systolic pressure ratio of 0.7. What is the correct interpretation of this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Intermittent claudication. Explanation: ABPI is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries). The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI. ABPI (Ankle brachial pressure index) or ABI (Ankle brachial index) here is 0.7 which indicates intermittent claudication in Buerger's disease. This index is calculated as: ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm Interpretations are as follows: Value Interpretation 0.1 - 0.4 Critical limb ischemia (Option A) 0.5 - 0.9 Intermittent claudication (Option B) 1.0 - 1.2 Normal (Option C) > 1.2 Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease) (Option D) Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1773

questions.question: What is the most specific investigation of choice for peripheral arterial disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CT angiography Explanation: CT angiography is considered the most specific investigation of choice due to: High resolution: High-resolution imaging of the entire vascular tree from the abdominal aorta to the foot arteries in a single examination. 3D reconstruction: Providing 3D reconstructions is crucial for intervention planning. Calcification detection: Accurate detection and quantification of arterial calcification. Less invasive: Less invasive than conventional angiography while maintaining detailed imaging. Characteristic radiological findings in peripheral arterial disease include: Disease confinement to distal circulation. Segmental occlusions with "skip" lesions. Extensive collateralization, notably "corkscrew" collaterals . Ankle-Brachial Index (Option A): It is a good screening tool but lacks specificity for detailed arterial mapping. Duplex ultrasonography (Option B): It is useful for initial evaluation but may have limitations in visualizing deeper arteries. Magnetic Resonance Angiography (Option D): It is also highly accurate but may be less available and more time-consuming than CT angiography.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with pain in his right calf that occurs after walking 200 meters and is relieved by rest. The pain does not occur when he is at rest or when he walks shorter distances. Based on Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication, which grade best describes this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grade II Explanation: The patient's pain occurs after walking 200 meters and is relieved by rest, which corresponds to Grade II claudication. Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication : Grade Description Grade 0: Asymptomatic (Option A ruled out) No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise Grade I: Mild claudication (Option B ruled out) Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade II: Moderate claudication (option C) Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade III: Severe claudication (Option D ruled out) Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 998, 999

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with pain in his hands and feet, which worsens with cold exposure. He has a history of heavy smoking. On examination, he has ulcers on his fingers and toes. Angiography reveals "corkscrew" collaterals and segmental occlusions. Which of the following conditions is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Thromboangiitis obliterans Explanation: The patient's age, heavy smoking history, and angiographic findings with "corkscrew" collaterals strongly indicate Buerger's Disease (Thromboangiitis obliterans). This condition involves inflammatory thrombosis affecting small and medium-sized vessels, primarily in the extremities. It presents with pain, ulcers, and claudication in both upper and lower limbs, often leading to gangrene if untreated. Smoking cessation is crucial for management, as it is the most important modifiable risk factor. Characteristic Buerger's Disease (Option B) Atherosclerosis (Option C) Age of onset Usually <45 years Typically >50 years Gender predominance Strong male predominance Male > Female Risk factors Heavy smoking (essential for diagnosis) Smoking, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia Pathophysiology Inflammatory thrombosis Lipid accumulation, inflammation, plaque formation Vessels affected Small and medium-sized arteries and veins Large and medium-sized arteries Distribution Upper and lower extremities equally Lower extremities > Upper extremities Progression Acute episodes with periods of remission Gradual onset, chronic course Diagnosis Angiography shows "corkscrew" collaterals, segmental occlusions Angiography shows irregular narrowing, calcification Treatment Smoking cessation is essential but has a limited role in revascularization. Risk factor modification, antiplatelet therapy, revascularisation Angiography shows "corkscrew" collaterals Systemic Sclerosis (Option A) is more common in middle-aged women and is characterized by skin thickening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and internal organ involvement. Angiography may show capillary changes but not the segmental occlusions seen in Buerger's Disease. Frostbite (Option D) is caused by exposure to extreme cold, leading to acute tissue damage in the extremities. It lacks the chronic inflammatory features and angiographic findings of Buerger's Disease.

questions.question: A 72-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of severe pain, numbness, and coldness in his left leg. On examination, the left leg appears pale, and no pulse is palpable below the femoral artery. What is the most probable cause of this acute peripheral arterial occlusion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Atherosclerosis Explanation: Atherosclerosis is the most likely cause due to the patient's advanced age and sudden onset of symptoms consistent with acute arterial occlusion. This condition typically affects individuals over 50 years and is associated with risk factors such as smoking, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Atherosclerosis involves lipid accumulation, inflammation, and plaque formation in large and medium-sized arteries, leading to a gradual but progressive narrowing that can result in sudden occlusion. Causes of peripheral arterial occlusion: Atherosclerosis (Most common) Embolism Thrombosis Trauma Vasculitis (e.g., Buerger’s disease) Fibromuscular dysplasia Arterial dissection Extrinsic compression Vessels involved and common sites of obstruction: Vessel Common Sites of Obstruction Related Manifestations/Findings Aorta Infrarenal aorta Bilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulses Iliac arteries Common iliac bifurcation Unilateral lower limb ischemia, absent femoral pulse Pain in the buttock is due to a block in the common iliac or aortoiliac segment (30%), often associated with impotence and is called as Leriche's syndrome. Femoral artery Common femoral artery Calf claudication, absent popliteal and distal pulses Popliteal artery Adductor canal Calf and foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses Tibial arteries Proximal or mid-calf Foot ischemia, absent pedal pulses Subclavian artery Proximal subclavian Arm ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses Subclavian steal syndrome: Obstruction of the first part of the subclavian artery can cause reverse blood flow through the vertebral artery, providing collateral circulation to the arm but affecting the posterior brain and upper limb, with steal being occult, partial, or complete. Brachial artery Mid-humerus level Forearm and hand ischemia, absent radial/ulnar pulses Buerger's disease (Option B): Unlikely due to the patient's age (72 years). It typically affects young adults under 45 , particularly heavy smokers. Fibromuscular dysplasia (Option C): Rare, non-inflammatory arterial disease, usually affecting women aged 30-50 . Commonly involves renal and carotid arteries. Arterial dissection (Option D): Less common in elderly patients. Usually, it occurs in larger arteries (aorta, major branches). The absence of severe, tearing back pain makes this less likely. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1024 Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 974
